title: Ulmer Data Science Stammtisch: DataScience Stammtisch at EvoBus
description:
On 26.09. another Data Science Stammtisch will take place. This time our host is Evobus Gmbh who invites us at 06:30pm to the Setra customer center.

A relaxed atmosphere, exciting lectures on data topics and a concluding networking & get together are waiting for you. Details for the Agenda will follow in the next days.

Please block the evening in the calendar and register here - the places are limited to 40. So don't hesitate! ;-)

--
Data Topics:

1.) KI-Dreiklang für ein erfolgreiches Business: Data Scientist, Domänen-Experte & Kunde (Dr. Christoph Oestreicher)

Wenn Data Scientists, Domänen-Experten und Kunden eng im Austausch stehen, geschieht etwas phänomenales. Der Data Scientist erfreut sich am Wert seiner Analysen. Der Domänen-Experte sieht seine zahlreichen Ideen in konkrete Produkte umgesetzt. Der Kunde hält Produkte in den Händen, die genau auf seinen Bedarf zielen. Wie oft habt Ihr so einen KI-Dreiklang schon gehört? Wir diskutieren gemeinsam konkrete Beispiele von Harmonie und Disharmonie.

AI triad for a successful business: Data Scientist, Domain Expert & Customer (Dr. Christoph Oestreicher)

When data scientists, domain experts and customers are in close contact, something phenomenal happens. The data scientists enjoy the value of their analysis. The domain experts see their numerous ideas implemented in tangible products. The customers hold products in their hands that are precisely targeted to their needs. How often have you listened to such an AI triad? We discuss practical examples of harmony and disharmony.

2.) Die Fabric Recognition App - Stofferkennung mit Hilfe von AI (Heiko Güßmann)

Immer wieder kommt es im After Sales vor, dass Stoffe von Sitzen erneuert werden müssen.
Doch die Suche nach dem passenden Stoff nimmt viel Zeit in Anspruch.
Mit der Fabric Recognition App kann aus über 2000 Stoffen, die richtige Materialnummer anhand von einem Foto ermittelt werden.
Dadurch erübrigt sich eine lange Suche nach der richtigen Materialnummer und der Stoff kann schnell getauscht werden.
Die Fortschritte im Bereich Bildklassifizierung mit Hilfe von AI machte diese Anwendung möglich.
Die hier eingesetzten Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) brachten eine bedeutende Verbesserung bei der Klassifizierung von Fotos und Objekten.

Vielen Dank schon vorab für eure Beiträge

title: Qatar Data Science, AI,Machine learning & Analytics Meetup: 3 Day Bootcamp on Data Science in Doha
group: Qatar Data Science, AI,Machine learning & Analytics Meetup
description:
Program objective
Build foundational skills in Data Science, Business Analytics and predictive modelling through the right mix of in-person and online training.

What will you learn
1. Understand the basics of R and R Studio
2. Learn the basics of statistics, data exploration, and data preparation
3. Understand the basic terminologies around Business Analytics, Data Science, Machine Learning & Artificial Intelligence
4. Learn to build business solutions with in-depth understanding and application of key regression modeling techniques
5. Learn to build business solutions with in-depth understanding and application of key classification & segmentation techniques
6. Experience real-life problem solving with real business data sets in the form of case studies and Capstone Project.

Skills you will build
Predictive modelling, Clustering, Forecasting, R programming, Data exploration, Data preparation, Statistics, Regression

Price: $999.00 /per person
Enroll Now: http://bit.ly/2V64Td1

Who should take this program
The course is suitable for you if you are one of the following:
•A business manager/ consultant who wants to leverage Data Science in his industry/ functional area.
•A mid-career professional who wants to build skills in Data Science for career growth
•An entry-level professional or a student who wants to build his career in Data Science.
•An academic who wants to get started with Data Science

What are the pre-requisites?
1. You should be a graduate
2. You should have basic knowledge of MS Excel.
This is a foundational program, hence there is no prior programming experience required to attend the program. However, if you are completely new to programming then you must go through the “Basics of Programming” module before you attend the classroom session.

Program Features
•3 days (30 hours) of in-person training with 5 hours of instructor-led live online training supported by self-paced modules
•CleveredLab, a platform that helps you learn by applying newly acquired knowledge in the classroom and later. The platform helps you experience the nitty-gritty of problem-solving and building the solutions.
•LEAP (Learning Environment for Analytics Professionals), an e-learning platform that provides the flexibility of learning anytime, anywhere and makes the learning convenient.
•Learning with real-world business problems: The program gives you an exposure to the actual business problems with real-world datasets from multiple industries.
•Sessions delivered by industry experts from organizations like Accenture Management Consulting, Barclays, Standard Chartered and HDFC bank.
•Program and pedagogy developed in collaboration with business leaders, domain experts and functional SMEs with rich experience in business consulting.
•Certificate of Participation and Project Completion Certificate
•A mix of in-person and live online sessions supported by self-paced content to provide the maximum value to the participants
•1 live online session for technical/career mentorship with a senior data scientist with 10+ years of experience.
•1 live online sessions for Q&A and discussions on case studies
•1 live online session for support on Capstone projects
•8 weekly quizzes
•3 capstone projects to expose the real world challenges to participants.
•Become a part of the community of Data Science enthusiasts and experts and solve your business problems. Know More -http://bit.ly/2V64Td1

title: Western Mass Statistics and Data Science: Research Bytes at Mass Mutual: Data provenance + monitoring of production models
group: Western Mass Statistics and Data Science
description:
Come join us at 5:30pm for refreshments and two short talks at 6:00pm.

Barbara Lerner (Mount Holyoke College): Making Provenance Work for You

To be useful, scientific results must be reproducible and trustworthy. Data provenance---the history of data and how it was computed---underlies reproducibility of and trust in data analyses. Our work focuses on collecting data provenance from R scripts and providing tools that use the provenance to increase the reproducibility of and trust in analyses done in R. Specifically, our ProvTools use data provenance to document the computing environment and inputs and outputs of a script's execution, support script debugging and exploration, and explain differences in behavior across repeated execution of the same script. Use of ProvTools can help both the original author and later users of a script reproduce and trust its results.

Adam Fox (MassMutual): Effective Monitoring of Production Models

Abstract: Data scientists can deliver significant value by automating or enhancing business processes using predictive models. There is also opportunity for these models to cause damage by producing invalid output as a result of data errors or population shifts. These systems must therefore be carefully monitored for problematic data. In this talk I will present MassMutual's model monitoring infrastructure and invite discussion on best practices

title: LA R users group: LA West R Users: September Meeting
description:
LA West R Users Group will have our September meeting at WeWork One Culver, 10000 Washington Boulevard Culver City CA 90232.

**Talk**
Speaker: Malcolm Barrett, Ph.D. student in Epidemiology at USC (@malco_barrett)

Title: Functional programming with purrr

Description: One of R’s most powerful features is that it’s a functional programming language. purrr is a consistent and efficient toolkit for programming with functions and working with lists. At its heart is `map()` and friends: functions for the common pattern of iterating over a vector or list, doing something to each element, and then storing the results. These functions let you iterate efficiently and with less code. As Jenny Bryan once said, “of course someone needs to write `for` loops; it doesn’t have to be you.”

Code of Conduct: https://github.com/laRusers/codeofconduct

**Schedule**
6:00-6:45 open door
6:45-7:30 talk starts (45min presentation + Q&A)
7:30-8:00 socialize
8:00 leave venue

**Venue**
Address: WeWork One Culver, 10000 Washington Boulevard, Culver City, CA 90232

Thanks to our sponsor Sabio Mobile (https://sabiomobile.com), food and drinks will be provided at the event. Come early to eat and hang out!

When you arrive: Bring a photo ID and scan it at the guest registration tablets at the front desk for the Meetup event. If your photo ID does not successfully scan, check in at the tablet as a guest of "Meetup Event".

15 min walk away from Expo Line Palms Station

title: LA R users group: LA East R Users: Deep learning with R & Run Python in RStudio with reticulate
description:
Talk 1:
Speaker: Huiyu Deng, PhD candidate in Biostatistics, University of Southern California
Title: A gentle Introduction Using R for Deep Learning

Abstract:
Do you know that R can also develop and evaluate deep learning models using Keras, one of the most popular deep learning libraries in Python? In this presentation, I will introduce the steps to set up the platform to run Keras in R and give you an overview of the concepts of neural network (NN) and deep learning models such as convolutional neural network (CNN). In the end, we will analyze a dataset using the Keras package.

Talk 2:
Speaker: Jo Hardin (@jo_hardin47), Professor, Pomona College
Title: reticulate: running Python within RStudio

Abstract:
A quick google search can quickly bring up many arguments on both sides of the heated Python vs R debate. I don’t take sides in that conversation, but I do recognize the value of knowing both languages and the power of being able to use one language inside software designed for the other. Whatever computational environment is used to execute instructions to the computer, it can be illuminating to see different implementations of the same syntax producing the same results, or alternatively, implementation of different syntax producing the same result. In this talk, I discuss running Python in the RStudio environment. I provided a series of examples in R Markdown chunks (both Python chunks and R chunks). I include details for those working with Python in R for the first time.

Code of Conduct: https://github.com/laRusers/codeofconduct

Timeline:
6:30: Socializing
7:00-8:00: Talks
8:00: Socializing

Address:
Room 115/116
USC
2001 N. Soto St.
Los Angeles, CA 90032

Parking: Parking is free in the metered spots on the east side of the parking lot after 5 PM

Invite yourself to our Slack group: http://bit.ly/laerug
Ask us any questions by email: [masked]
Find our previous talks on GitHub: https://github.com/laRusers/presentations
Follow us on Twitter: @la_Rusers
Check out more events: https://laocr.org/

title: R Generation: Creating beautiful analytics dashboards in R
description: The dashboard is an excellent tool for presenting performance measures such as business KPIs as well as general trends and patterns in data. Dashboards can also serve as a canvas from which to tell a story with your data. In this workshop, we will use the flexdashboard package to build an elegant dashboard that contains interactive data visualisation components along with other nice features such as gauges and dials.

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Advanced Regression Models with R Applications
description:
**SIGN UP ON EVENTBRITE **
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/ocrug-advanced-regression-models-with-r-applications-tickets-70416075377

In this workshop, we will talk about a variety of regression models, give their definitions, discussing goodness-of-fit criteria, presenting fitted models, interpreting estimated regression coefficients, and using the fitted models for prediction. The models will be limited to: linear regression, Box-Cox transformation, gamma regression, ordinary logistic regression, Poisson regression, beta regression, longitudinal (repeated measures) regression, and hierarchical model.

The workshop is designed to be hands-on. Participants are required to bring laptops and be ready to write R, analyzing data and interpreting results. For each model, we present an example with a complete R code, and then will an exercise to work on. Workshop participants should be familiar with algebraic expressions of different probability distributions and have a fundamental knowledge of simple linear regression: normally distributed random error, continuous and categorical independent variables (requiring creating dummy variables).

The material covered by the workshop will be taken from my recently published book “Advanced Regression Models with SAS and R Applications”, CRC Press, 2018.

title: Orange County R Users Group (OCRUG): Using YAML and Python in your R Workflow
description:
# Introduction

Malcolm has been interning with RStudio and working on a package, ymlthis, which will allow you too write YAML code using R. The goal is to make it easier to create the metadata needed by markdown, bookdown, blogdown and other frameworks used in R.

R and Python are both popular languages in Data Science. There is no need to limit yourself to just one. Michael will show us how to incorporate python into your R workflow.

Come early, network, enjoy the food and talks.

# Schedule
6:30 - 6:50 Networking
6:50 - 7:00 Welcome & general announcement
7:00 - 7:30 The YAML problem: Writing and working with YAML with ymlthis
7:30 - 8:00 Snakes in the Studio: Adding Python to your R Workflow
8:00 - Raffle
8:00 - 8:30 Networking and Clean-up

# Talk 1

## Title: The YAML problem: Writing and working with YAML with ymlthis
## Speaker: Malcolm Barrett
## Abstract
R Markdown is an easy-to-learn tool for reproducible research. Many people, however, bump into problems using YAML, the language that specifies metadata for R Markdown documents. ymlthis makes it easy to write valid YAML by handling the syntax and documenting the majority of YAML fields in one place. ymlthis will help you write metadata for R Markdown, bookdown, blogdown, and more. Let the Shiny add-in create a new R Markdown file for you or work with YAML and R Markdown files directly. ymlthis finally gives you a workflow that is better than trying to find and paste the YAML from the last R Markdown document you used.

# Talk 2

## Title: Snakes in the Studio: Adding Python to your R Workflow
## Speaker: Michael Espero
## Abstract
R and Python are among the most widely used programming languages for analysts and data scientists. While it’s great to feel comfortable in one open-source statistical programming language, you may encounter peers who prefer another. This walk-through aims to share some of RStudio’s versatility as we touch on useful commonalities between data science workflows in R and Python with attention to simple approaches to loading, wrangling, visualizing, and modelling publicly available data.

title: Vancouver Data Visualization: [x-post] Data and Visualization meet Sustainability Entrepreneurship
description:
We are happy to co-host another meetup with the "Data Science for Social Good" group.

To make it easier to keep track of attendees
▻ PLEASE RSVP HERE ◅
https://www.meetup.com/meetup-group-vancouver-data-science-for-social-good/events/264409115

__WHAT'S EN4S?__
We are proud to hold an evening of presentations in support of the Entrepreneurs for Sustainability (EN4S) initiative. EN4S is a month-long series of events gathering fresh and bright minds for tackling sustainable energy issues, taking place in September & October 2019 in downtown Vancouver.
See more details about the entire EN4S initiative here: https://en4s.bcsea.org

__AGENDA__
5:30 Doors open
6:00 Intro
6:10 Presentations
7:30 Networking & Mingling

__PRESENTATIONS__

► LEAH HANVEY
▻ Better Urban Planning for the Planet

Leah is a Business Development Manager at Urban Logiq (www.urbanlogiq.com - our host venue) and former research advisor for GLOBE Advisors in Vancouver. Leah is a former Advisor to the federal Minister of Small Business and Tourism and Government House Leader. Leah was also a technical analyst in financial modeling for Deloitte, completed an exchange at the University of Zurich in banking and finance and worked at the Vancouver Economic Commission performing economic research.

► ANTHONY PAK
▻ Assessing the environmental impact of building materials

Anthony is the Principal of Priopta which provides parametric Life Cycle Assessments (LCA) for buildings. Those assessments enable architects, engineers, and developers to design buildings that use materials with significantly lower embodied environmental impact. A wide range of material design options are being analyzed and visualized to help the customers quickly compare material options and make informed decisions. He loves to visualize interesting environmental data and will be showcasing a few data visualization projects relating to buildings, energy policy, climate solutions, and food impacts.

► YULIANA PROENZA
▻ Exploring historical Geothermal Data: GIS and 3D Visualization of Mount Meager

Yuliana is a Geologist working in the mineral exploration field since 2006 at various deposits across Canada at different stages of exploration and development. For her Master’s thesis she was compiling and evaluating historical exploration data available for the Upper Lillooet geothermal area, associated with the Mount Meager volcanic complex, located 150 kilometres north of Vancouver. She provided a data foundation and 3D visuals for that data, which includes geochemical results for springs and well fluids, consolidation of general geology and structural mapping, and drilling data including collar locations, survey deviation data, downhole lithology and temperature measurements.

► ELENA POPOVICI
▻ Entrepreneurship in the age of data science

Elena is a Computer Science PhD with over a dozen years of industry experience managing science-driven projects using algorithms to solve complex, real-world business and engineering problems across a wide variety of domains. Elena is currently a Project Lead at Neurio, where she uses machine learning to forecast electricity consumption and generation from solar panels, and optimization to intelligently operate a battery based on these forecasts in order to reduce the grid demand during peak periods. Elena also volunteers with the BC Sustainable Energy Association and co-organizes the Data Science for Social Good meetup.

title: Vancouver Data Visualization: IEEE VIS meets Vancouver
description:
IEEE VIS (http://ieeevis.org), one of the highest rated conferences for visualization research and computer graphics, is in Vancouver this year!

We think this is a great opportunity for the international visitors to see what’s happening in Vancouver's Data Viz community, and for the locals (who might not be able to attend the conference) to get a glimpse of the latest research in that area.

☞ TELL US ABOUT YOUR WORK!
Anybody who is willing to share their visualization work (research, projects, ideas) we'd love to see a 2-5 minute presentation from you!
Feel free to contact me, then we can talk about the details and I'll put you on the agenda - or just come by and we'll play it by ear.

We'll kick it off with those presentations and then should have enough time afterwards to network, ask follow-up questions, mingle and eat pizza.

BrainStation (https://brainstation.io) will host us this time - many thanks!!

It's a great venue - and super conveniently close to the Convention Center, where the conference is at (5 minute walk)

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group
description:
Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: St. Petersburg R User Group: SPbR #15
description:
Василий Каминский, тех. аналитик, JetBrains
Анализ временных рядов

На работе я регулярно сталкиваюсь с задачами анализа и прогнозирования временных рядов. В своём рассказе я затрону базовые понятия, принципы и модели временных рядов (AR, MA и их более сложные модификации) с примерами на языке R. Доклад будет полезен начинающим аналитикам, аналитикам данных, специалистам по машинному обучению и всем заинтересованным.

Владимир Завьялов, специалист по измерительным машинам
Использование R в машиностроении

Рассказ о том как R упростил анализ результатов измерения на производстве электромеханических приводов.

Владимир Кошелев, разработчик R Plugin, JetBrains
R Plugin

Компания JetBrains последнее время разрабатывает плагин к PyCharm для языка R. В своем докладе я покажу и расскажу, что у нас получилось.

*****
Самая актуальная информация, материалы и записи докладов в группе https://vk.com/spbrug

Обратите внимание: в этот раз мы встречаемся в новом офисе JetBrains у метро Беговая.

title: Greater Toronto Area (GTA) R User Group: October R meetup - two talks about R + network with other R enthusiasts!
group: Greater Toronto Area (GTA) R User Group
description:
Join us for the October meetup of the Toronto R group! We will have two featured talks:

*Michael Enquist* will be talking about Association Rules in R and how to apply them to grocery shopping. Association rules are statements that help to find patterns in seemingly unrelated data or a relational database (information repository). When we apply to a user purchasing a product, we will try to show five other products that the user is most likely to buy together with this product.

*Madeleine Bonsma-Fisher* (and possibly some of her collaborators) will be talking about a graduate student-led participatory live-coding quantitative methods course in R.

Doors will open at 6:00pm, with talks kicking off at 6:30. After the talks you're welcome to stick around for some networking, and by 8:00 we'll leave the room (but may head somewhere nearby to continue the conversation!).

The event will be held at Insight Data Science, so please remember to thank them.

By attending, you agree to abide by our code of conduct which can be found at https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: Meetup R Nantes: Cartographie avec R et d3.js
description:
Les cartes sont omniprésentes, mais les règles qui président à leur construction restent souvent méconnues. Avec R, faire des cartes est simple. Faire de "belles" cartes plus compliqué. Faire des cartes "pertinentes" plus encore. Et quid de l'interactivité ? En 1h, nous nous intéressons / parcourrons l'univers de la cartographie pour le data-scientist et expliquerons les erreurs les plus courantes. Nous finirons par une exploration de ce que peut apporter l'interactivité avec des exemples en d3.js.

Arthur Katossky est enseignant en informatique, statistique et économie à l'ENSAI (Rennes) où il donne entre autres les cours de visualisation de données. Auparavant, il est passé par la finance, l'immobilier, l'enseignement, la recherche, le marketing, l'écologie... en France et au Danemark, dans le public et dans le privé.
Son twitter : https://twitter.com/akatossky .

description:
golem : un framework pour concevoir des applications shiny robustes dans un cadre professionnel

Présenté par Vincent Guyader de ThinkR.

title: Meetup R Nantes: Deep leaRning, il n'y a pas que le python dans la vie
description:
ATTENTION : Exceptionnellement, ce meetup aura lieu dans les locaux de Valeuriad (14 rue François Evellin à Nantes) !

Plus de détails à venir...

Passionné par l'informatique et le machine learning et après une première vie dans la recherche, Nicolas Greffard est aujourd'hui data scientist et responsable de l'innovation chez Valeuriad où il intervient sur des missions de conseil et d'expertise autour de la data science.

title: Meetup R Nantes: "Rmd first" : Quand le développement commence par la documentation...
description:
Titre complet : "Rmd first" : Quand le développement commence par la documentation (ou "N'ayez pas peur de faire un package...")

Les analyses, les programmes R ou les packages sont plus faciles à utiliser et à maintenir lorsqu'ils sont correctement documentés. Cependant, la documentation semble prendre beaucoup de temps et, lorsqu'elle est incluse, elle est habituellement la dernière chose ajoutée à un projet. Pour un projet reproductible, les workflows peuvent être présentés dans un fichier Rmarkdown, combinant explications et analyses. Nous allons nous appuyer sur ce format Rmd pour s'assurer de la pérennité de nos travaux.
Nous tenterons au passage de désacraliser la création de package. En continuant d'écrire notre code (presque) comme d'habitude mais en faisant les bons copier-coller au bon moment, on peut développer des analyses avec toute la documentation nécessaire sans (trop d')efforts. Le format package simplifie le partage, les tests, la maintenance et la présentation de son travail.

Sébastien Rochette est formateur-consultant en R chez ThinkR. Avant de rejoindre le privé, il est passé par un doctorat en écologie halieutique à Agrocampus Ouest (Rennes), puis un poste de chercheur en cartographie des habitats marins à Ifremer Brest.
Son site web : https://statnmap.com
Son twitter : https://twitter.com/statnmap

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): October useR Group: Shiny in Production!
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
Shiny in Production!
Presented by Sean Lopp, RStudio

Abstract:
Shiny is an R package that makes it easy to build interactive web apps straight from R, a language not traditionally known for web frameworks, to say the least. As such, Shiny has always faced questions about whether it can or should be used “in production”. In this talk, we’ll explore what “production” even means, review some of the historical obstacles and objections to using Shiny for production purposes, and discuss practices and tools that can help your Shiny apps flourish.

Bio:
Sean Lopp is a Product Manager at RStudio. Sean leads teams to create useful, enjoyable products. Before RStudio he was a data scientist and worked on alternative vehicle models at NREL, infant sleep dynamics, and originally studied mathematics. He lives outside Denver, CO and skis and bikes with his family.

We welcome all newcomers, enthusiasts, and experts.

* Pizza will be provided by RStudio
* Event location provided by WeWork

WeWork is a global network of workspaces where companies grow together. Teams of any size can find refreshingly designed collaborative space, private offices, and meeting rooms that energize their employees and their guests. But WeWork is so much more than four walls—providing community, amenities, events, and technology to evolve space into experience.

title: Boston R/Bioconductor for Genomics: Bioconductor, Docker and  Containers (POSTPONED, date TBC)
description:
*POSTPONED*

Bioconductor Docker & Containers

Bioconductor provides a range of options which allow users and developers to perform their analysis using containers, taking away the burden of installing dependencies and system requirements. Containers allow software to be used in a reproducible, reliable and isolated fashion.

Bioconductor also produces containers which replicate their build machines to allow developers contributing to the project to test their changes more aggressively before being put in production. These containers will provide the base infrastructure for cloud/web platforms in the near future. This talk will highlight how to use these containers effectively through docker on your local machine and demo their usage in the cloud.

Nitesh Turaga
Bioconductor Core Team, Roswell Park
https://www.bioconductor.org/about/core-team/
I'm a Senior Programmer in the Core team at the Bioconductor Project. I've been building open source bioinformatics software since 2013, first at the Galaxy Project at Johns Hopkins and now at the Bioconductor Project. I'm passionate about programming, R, and data

https://github.com/nturaga

title: DuPage R Meetup: Data Mining with Amazon Web Services by Andy Roy
description:
Data Mining with Amazon Web Services by Andy Roy. Use the power of cloud-based services to enhance and visualize relationships in your business or personal data. Most business analysts are constrained by Excel to simplistic data visualization. We will review several techniques in R to automate tasks and produce colorful, engaging insights from the data you already have in Excel or business databases. This talk will be approachable for beginners and interesting for advanced R users as well. The code demonstrated will be shared via GitHub, and the packages we will review included aws, comprehend (NLP), pdftools & officer (text scraping), dplyr & ggplot, visNetwork (directed graphs), mongolite (MongoDB in the cloud), and Shiny.

Andy will start his presentation at about 6:00. We'll have meet-n-greet both before and after. You do not need to show up exactly at 5:30 nor stay until 8. Thanks to Innovation DuPage and Benedictine University for the free pizza and pop and free meeting space.

About the Speaker: Andy Roy is a digital marketing consultant with 30+ years industry experience in companies such as Neustar, Wipro Digital, Experian, Razorfish and Microsoft. His interest in R comes from developing business reporting applications.

About Innovation DuPage: https://innovationdupage.org/

title: CopenhagenR - useR Group: Smooth curves in R and Xaringan shenanigans
description:
Two exciting upcoming talks:

Smooth curves in R by Niels Lundtorp Olsen
===========================================

R is a great and flexible software but lacks an easy and fast package for dealing curves such as in functional data and vector graphics.
This talk will not be about all the cool tools for making plots, but we will go one step behind and look at how smooth curves are represented as data in a computer, and how to implement this in R.
Doing things fast in R often means doing it in C++, which also will bring us past object-oriented programming. In the end, we get a package that can easily be applied to functional data and elsewhere. This is work in progress and feedback will be appreciated.

Xaringan shenanigans by Claus Thorn Ekstrøm
=============================================
R provides several possibilities for using Rmarkdown to quickly create
excellent presentations combining R code, R output, mathematics,
animations, and interactive widgets.

In this code-along I will show how to use the package xaringan to
build simple, elegant, Rmarkdown-driven presentations based on the
remark.js presentation framework. We will cover formatting, widgets,
caveats, show some tips and tricks, and how to customise your own
presentation template.

title: CopenhagenR - useR Group: Data R for Kids
description:
Exciting talk and co-creation event by Sine Zambach:

Data R for Kids
==============

We know from tobacco industry, that we should get’em while they are young. But if we should get young people using in R – what would it require? To a start [someone] should develop a new set of exercises that can engage kids and young people to explore data science and (R)-programming. Not sports results or airplane time tables. Exercises should be simple and funny and relate to the everyday of the young students.
This event is a co-creation, and I will only entertain briefly. After this, we are all in center in designing and perhaps taking the first steps in having a library of R-exercises for kids.

title: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga: 8ª reunión de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga
group: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga
description:
Hola, tras la consulta Doodle que realizamos a todos vosotros, os informamos de la fecha que ha logrado mayor consenso.

Jueves 26 de Septiembre a las 19:00. La duración será de una hora a hora y media como mucho.

Título: RR - Reproducible Research in R (Rmarkdown)
Autor: Domingo López
(solo en inglés el título)

"R integra un conjunto de herramientas que permite que cualquier persona puede reproducir los resultados bajo las mismas condiciones. Esto es posible gracias a los documentos dinámicos - dynamic documents (literate programming, Donald Knuth, 1984).

El producto final de un análisis, o de una investigación no es solo un
informe o un artículo, es también el entorno computacional completo para reproducir los resultados, el código y los datos.

Desde R podemos generar documentos dinámicos que integren:
- los datos usados
- Latex
- explicaciones
- código en R o en otros lenguajes
- resultados (solo resultados y no el código, solo el código, todo)

Desde R, usando la herramienta denominada RMarkdown podemos generar informes, presentaciones en pdf o beamer, libros, webs de alta calidad, siguiendo el paradigma de la investigación reproducible."

Con esta charla que nos dará Domingo queremos dar una introducción a Rmarkdown para que comencéis a elaborar presentaciones desde Rstudio.

Cuidado: Cuando comiences a usar RMarkdown,... no hay marcha atrás.

Lugar: Laboratorio[masked] (sitio habitual de anteriores charlas).

Recomendación - traer vuestro portátil los que podáis y tengáis acceso a la wifi de la UMA. Andamos renovando laboratorio, para los que no tengáis acceso a la wifi de la UMA, usaremos los ordenadores que tenemos. Dar las gracias al Departamento de Matemática Aplicada por su colaboración.

Límite de asistentes: 50 plazas

Si necesitáramos algo especial os lo decimos estos días.

Como siempre, luego una/s cerveza/s y/o refresco/s.

Com siempre, si conocéis a alguien que se apuntó antes en el grupo de usuarios pero no está en Meetup, por favor, indicarle que a partir de ahora trabajamos para coordinarnos usando Meetup.

Manda esta información a interesados en nuestro grupo.

¡Un saludo!

title: Greater Cleveland R Group: Real-time file import with the vroom package (Jim Hester)
description:
File import in R could be considered a solved problem, with multiple widely used packages (data.table, readr, and others) providing fast, robust import of common formats in addition to the functions available in base R.

However I feel there is still room for improvement in existing approaches. vroom is able to index and then query multi-Gigabyte files, including those with categorical, text and temporal data, in near real-time, parsing at over 1 Gb per second.

This is a huge boon for interactive data analysis as you can jump directly into exploratory analysis without sampling or long waits for full import.

vroom leverages the Altrep framework introduced in R 3.5 along with lazy, just-in-time parsing of the data to provide this improved latency without requiring changes to existing data manipulation code.

I will thoroughly explain the techniques used in vroom to ensure good performance, describe challenges overcome in implementing it, and provide an interactive demonstration of its capabilities.

vroom is on CRAN now, install it with `install.packages("vroom")` and learn more about the package at https://vroom.r-lib.org

title: Greater Cleveland R Group: Teaching Lab R&D Chemists using RMD and Shiny with Mukul Mehta
description:
Lab R&D Chemists in Chemical, Food, Plastic, Polymer and Pharma industries are very creative and constantly develop new products over time. Their R&D Managers worry, that R&D is very slow and struggle to speed up NPD. Many big companies like DuPont, Dow, BF Goodrich Chemical and others have tried to bring new statistical and mathematical methods in-house, but without much success.

Mukul Mehta will examine several problems he has identified and an R/Shiny based solution that he is developing to address these problems. Mukul hopes to train 10,000 Lab R&D chemists over three years.

title: Sevilla R Users: Reunión SevillaR: 1 Octubre. Procesamiento de Lenguaje Natural con R
description:
¡Empezamos nuevo curso en SevillaR!

El próximo martes 1 de Octubre Montse López Cobo (https://www.linkedin.com/in/montserrat-l%C3%B3pez-cobo-25069ab1/), Scientific Project Officer en el Joint Research Centre de la Unión Europea, nos hablará sobre Procesamiento del Lenguaje Natural con R.

El procesamiento del lenguaje natural (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing) es un campo en intenso desarrollo y con múltiples aplicaciones, como la minería y análisis de textos, interpretación y generación del lenguaje, chatbots, etc.

El encuentro será en el aula TIC4 (2ª planta) del edificio CRAI (https://bib.us.es/ulloa) del campus de Reina Mercedes, a las 19 horas.

Tras la conferencia tendremos la oportunidad de hablar sobre nuestros proyectos en R y conocernos mejor tomando unas cervezas en el Aljibe, muy cercano al CRAI.

¡Os esperamos!

title: IndyUseR Group: Reproducible workflows at scale with drake
description: Ambitious workflows in R, such as machine learning analyses, can be difficult to manage. A single round of computation can take several hours to complete, and routine updates to the code and data tend to invalidate hard-earned results. You can enhance the maintainability, hygiene, speed, scale, and reproducibility of such projects with the drake R package. drake resolves the dependency structure of your analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and organizes the output so you rarely have to think about data files. This talk demonstrates how to create and maintain a realistic machine learning project using drake-powered automation.

title: Greater Portland useR Group (R programming language): The ETL Machine: An approach to ETL in R, Part 1 - Writing good functions
group: Greater Portland useR Group (R programming language)
description:
There are lots of good reasons to avoid using R for ETL. But that doesn't mean one shouldn't try. Sometimes business constraints and lack of adequate tools make ETL orchestration far more painful than it needs to be. That is why David Denton is currently endeavoring to build a robust, portable, ETL Machine with R & Shiny. This is a work in progress that he is sharing in hopes of eliciting some helpful feedback (booing and hissing is acceptable as well). Part 1 will focus on writing versatile, well-documented functions in R.

David Denton currently works as a data engineer at the Maine Medical Center Research Institute.

Pizza and beverages will be provided.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Using R for geospatial applications at the USDA
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our next Meetup will be downtown at Neumont College. City Creek has free two hour parking or you can take the Trax blue or green line to the Gallivan Plaza or City Center stations. Phil Roberts from the USDA will present.

Summary: The US Department of Agriculture is using R / RStudio to solve a variety of geospatial data questions.  We will discuss various geospatial data models and how they are handled in R, as well as some of the relevant packages for dealing with geographic data.  We will look at how the National Cooperative Soil Survey and the Aerial Photography Field Office are improving current methods, with more explicit and quantitative approaches to current workflows.  USDA Staff have developed innovative packages (AQP, SharpshootR, SoilDB, cLHS) to help with the visualization and analysis of soil profile data.  We discuss an example of how USDA is applying machine learning to aerial imagery to learn changes in the agricultural landscape.

Bio: I’ve been using R and R Studio for ~12 years, and it represented my first introduction to coding.  I graduated from Cal Poly San Luis Obispo with a BS Earth Science and a BS in Soil Science and went on to earn a MS in Soil Science from Washington State University.  I started my career with the USDA in 2009 as a soil scientist in Mt Vernon, Washington mapping Soils and Ecological Sites at North Cascades, Mount Rainier and Olympic National Parks.  Last year I accepted a position as a cartographer here in Salt Lake City where my current project involves applying machine learning to aerial imagery to map land cover and relating these maps to farm records databases.  I use R to solve geospatial problems such as, sample design, data clustering, data visualizations, predictive modeling and quality control. 

The meeting will be live streamed on YouTube on the Utah R Users Group channel.

title: Oslo useR! Group: OsloUseR::inner_join(). OUR community meeting
description:
Dear R-enthusiasts,

You might have noticed that we announced community meeting on 15 October 2019. The purpose of this event is to look back at the events we enjoyed last year, celebrate growth and diversity of our community and discuss the road ahead. We will have a few lightning talks (10-15 min) on diverse subjects and leave time for discussions and reflections on how UseR meetups helped you grow or learn in the last year.

In order to ensure constant flow of fun and useful events, we need to have people organizing them and making sure speakers, venues and practicalities are taken care of in time for every new UseR meeting. We would like to elect Organizing Committee consisting of 5-6 members, who would take on responsibility to serve the community in the next 12 months. Here are some of the topics that Organizing Committee will assume responsibility for:
1) Recruiting speakers for the events
2) Arranging venues
3) Applying for and arranging sponsor support for the group
4) Keeping community informed through timely announcements and event marketing
5) Maintaining relationship with partner organizations, such as R-Ladies, global UseR network, and other meetups in Oslo.

Based on the experience from last year, these duties should not take more than 3-4 hours per month, but we want to avoid the situation where everyone assumes somebody else is taking care of a particular issue and in the end no one steps up to the responsibility.

Acting as a Meetup Organizer goes beyond the line on the resume. It means meeting new people, expanding your network and talking to colleagues in senior positions in data community. You also make yourself known to the wider community of R users around the world, get inspired to pursue cool projects and interesting ideas and generally grow as an R programmer and a data professional.

We are hereby inviting you to nominate yourself to a community service position at the Oslo UseR Organizing Committee! If you have been enjoying our meetups, now you have the chance to make sure others can enjoy them, too!

Please, post your name and a couple of sentences describing your motivation for serving at the Oslo UseR Organizing Committee for the year 2019/2020 here:
https://www.meetup.com/Oslo-useR-Group/messages/boards/thread/52386458/0/

Thank you very much for your dedication to spreading knowledge of R and your support for Oslo UseR community!

On behalf of interim Organizer Committee,

Dmytro

title: Saint Louis R User Group: Machine Learning in R with mlr3
description:
By: Matt Dube

mlr3 (https://mlr3.mlr-org.com/) is the next generation of the mlr R package. It provides a generic, object-oriented, and extensible framework for classification, regression, survival analysis, and other machine learning tasks for the R language.

This discussion will take a brief look at the past and present of machine learning in R, and then take a detailed look at how mlr3 attempts to refine and improve the current processes and tools. This will include a sample project code walkthrough, and references for further study.

The meetup will be in The Showroom in the CIC building at 20 South Sarah Street, St. Louis, MO 63108. The building entrance is at the corner of Forest Park Avenue and Sarah Street. You can find directions at http://stl.cic.us/directions/ (CIC@CET).

We will meet for snacks, set-up, and conversation at 6:00PM. The presentation will start at 6:30PM and will be about 60 minutes long.

title: Portland R User Group: ruODK? Electronic Data Capture with R and ODK: From form design to insight in 0$
description:
Electronic Data Capture (EDC) as a replacement for traditional paper-based data capture can streamline the path from observation to analysis by cutting out redundant, resource-intensive, and error-prone steps of data transcription. OpenDataKit (ODK, https://opendatakit.org/) is a Free and Open Source (FOSS) software suite for EDC. ODK has a world-wide user community (https://forum.opendatakit.org/), an active developer community, a sustainable business model, comes at no cost to users, and is targeted towards resource-restricted, remote and offline data capture. ODK users include Google, WHO, CDC, USAID, the Red Cross and Red Crescent, the Carter Center, the Jane Goodall Institute and many others.
​
In this session, we will run through the process of EDC end to end, with the option of participating in each step.
We will design a new EDC form using the online form builder ODK Build (https://build.opendatakit.org/), then publish the form on DBCA's ODK Central instance (https://odkcentral.dbca.wa.gov.au/, credentials given out on the day), download the forms, capture and submit some data using ODK Collect, and lastly use ruODK to access, wrangle, and analyse the data using ruODK.
​
Interested participants can obtain a login to the ODK Central Sandbox (https://sandbox.central.opendatakit.org/), so they can continue to evaluate ODK (with our without ruODK) in a no-cost environment.

Details
​
Activity: Live demo and code-along for those who are keen

Duration: ca 45 mins; some prep for audience hands-on beforehand

Target audience: Practicing R users with an interest in electronic data capture using FOSS.

If interested in hands-on, bring:
* To build your own form: Sign up for a free account at https://build.opendatakit.org/
* To collect your own data: Bring an Android device with ODK Collect installed.
* To access and analyse the data: Bring a Laptop with R and ruODK with dependencies intstalled (https://dbca-wa.github.io/ruODK/)
Come 30 mins early to do your ruODK/ODK Collect installation on the day.
​​
​​About the presenter
​
Florian Mayer is an Ecoinformatician at the Western Australian Department of Biodiversity, Conservation and Attractions (DBCA) working on threatened species and ecological communities with a focus on marine turtles (North West Shelf Flatback Turtle Conservation Program, https://flatbacks.dbca.wa.gov.au/). Florian has introduced ODK to DBCA's and affiliated Western Australian turtle monitoring programs in 2016 (~30k records captured through ~500 staff and volunteers since 2016) and authored ruODK.
​

title: SheffieldR - Sheffield R Users Group: Hacktoberfest 2019 - Kick Off
description:
Research Software Engineering (RSE) @ Sheffield (https://rse.shef.ac.uk/), Sheffield Bioinformatics Hub (https://sbc.shef.ac.uk/) & Sheffield R User Group welcome you to Hacktoberfest 2019! Starts 1st Oct. & every Tuesday evening in October.

Hacktoberfest is back! a one-month celebration of open source software, all about encouraging meaningful contributions to the open source ecosystem, for beginners and veterans alike.

We’re offering a range of sessions, open to anyone (not just R users!) in a friendly, informal environment, as a great opportunity to learn more about:

- open source and the huge diversity of projects available for contribution.
- how to find projects, tasks and ways to contribute.
- version control through git and GitHub.
- programming and software development.
- effective collaboration online.

Make five contributions to projects on GitHub during October and get a Hacktoberfest t-shirt!

Sessions
Introductory session
1st Oct. 5.30- 7.30 pm, The Red Deer

We’ll kick off with an introductory session on open source on Tues 1st October. The focus of the session will be on using GitHub to explore and contribute to open source and is not limited to R users. Feel free to bring your laptop and follow allow to get yourself set up, practice and get ready to contribute.

Hacky hour sessions
Meeting room 1, the Diamond, 5:30 pm to 8:00 pm
The University of Sheffield, 32 Leavygreave Rd, S3 7RD

For every following Tuesday evening of October, we’ve booked a room to explore Hacktoberfest projects together! The room is booked on the following dates:

- 08 October
- 15 October
- 22 October
- 29 October

(If you don't have a TUoS swipe card, please register here for a pass to the Diamond: https://forms.gle/iwBKYLVoC5uouUCg7)

Come to as many sessions as you like, stay as long as you can, bring your friends! If anyone gets stuck, there’ll be others around to help. There’ll also be at least one member of the RSE team at each session to help with questions and demystifying any open source jargon.

By the end, hopefully, you’ll have had an opportunity to learn more about collaboration, play around with something new and managed to contribute and get the t-shirt to prove it!

Hope to see you there!

Please read our Events Code of Conduct (https://do.co/hacktoberconduct) before attending. Happy hacking!

Find out more about Hacktoberefest: https://hacktoberfest.digitalocean.com/

title: Bay Area useR Group (R Programming Language): Time Series Workshop
group: Bay Area useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
We are trying something new for BARUG, offering a Saturday morning workshop where we can spend more time "hands on" working with R code. Rami Krispin will present our first workshop on Time Series Analysis. Rami is a data scientist that focuses on time series analysis and forecasting. He is the author of "Hands-On Time Series Analysis with R" and several R packages, including the TSstudio package for time series analysis and forecasting applications.

The workshop is free but seating is limited. If you do not RSVP for the event you may not get in.

The agenda for the morning is as follows:

8:00 AM - doors open
8:30 Workshop Begins
8:30 - 9:00 Introduction to time series analysis and forecasting
a) An overview of the forecasting process
b) Packages and tools
9:30 - 10:00 Time series objects - introduction to the time series classes and their attributes:
a) ts
b) xts and zoo
c) tsibble
10:00 - 10:30 Descriptive analysis of time series:
a) Correlation analysis - acf and pacf functions, lags plots, etc.
b) Seasonal analysis
10:30 - 10:45 Break
10:45 - 11:30 Linear regression-based forecasting models:
a) Feature engineering - decomposing the time series
components into regression features
b) Handling special events, holidays, outliers, etc
11:30 - 12:30 The ARIMA family of models:
a) Stationarity and differencing
b) AR process
c) MA process
d) ARMA and ARIMA model
e) Seasonal ARIMA
f) Linear regression with ARIMA errors

title: Melbourne Users of R Network (MelbURN): Exploring longitudinal data and Production-Ready R model using AWS
description:
Two separate topics for this meetup;
Exploring Longitudinal data with the brolgar package
Productionising models in AWS using SageMaker

Thanks again to Servian for venue and catering!

Rough agenda:
5:45: Networking, food & drinks
6:15 First presentation
7:00 Second presentation
7:45 More networking
8:30 Close

First presentation: Making better spaghetti (plots): Exploring the individuals in longitudinal data with the brolgar package

Longitudinal (panel) data provide the opportunity to examine temporal patterns of individuals, because measurements are collected on the same person at different, and often irregular, time points. The data is typically visualised using a "spaghetti plot", where a line plot is drawn for each individual. When overlaid in one plot, it can have the appearance of a bowl of spaghetti. With even a small number of subjects, these plots are too overloaded to be read easily. The interesting aspects of individual differences are lost in the noise.

Longitudinal data is often modeled with a hierarchical linear model to capture the overall trends, and variation among individuals, while accounting for various levels of dependence. However, these models can be difficult to fit, and can miss unusual individual patterns. Better visual tools can help to diagnose longitudinal models, and better capture the individual experiences.

In this talk, Nick will introduce the R package, **brolgar** (BRowse over Longitudinal data Graphically and Analytically in R), which provides tools to identify and summarise interesting individual patterns in longitudinal data.

Dr. Nick Tierney completed his PhD in Statistics at QUT and is now a Lecturer at Monash University. Nick's research aims to improve data analysis workflow. This includes statistical modelling, calculating diagnostics, drawing inferences and making decisions. Crucial to this work is producing high quality software to accompany each research idea. His work so far has focussed on the importance of knowing your data ( in the R package, visdat ), and on creating principles and tools that make it easier to work with, explore, and model missing data (in the R package, naniar). Nick has also created an optimisation model that identifies and possibly relocates facilities to maximise their coverage on a population, in the R package maxcovr. Nick loves the R programming language and how it has transformed his world. He is a proud member of the rOpenSci community, a collective that works to make science open using R, and co-host a podcast with Dr. Saskia Freytag about everything #rstats named “Credibly Curious”.

Second presentation: Building Scalable Production-Ready R model using AWS

In this growing world of Machine Learning, we often roam around creating POCs (proof-of-concepts), but an important aspect that is often forgotten is how we bring models from POC and into production. The thing is, productionising your model and ensuring scalability is not as easy as a click of a button or minor code change. Even after you get your model into production, we must re-evaluate our model, perform A/B testing and redeploy our model. This is all part of the data science pipeline. All of these steps are time-consuming and require many configurational changes.

In this presentation, Jeno will present how everyday data scientists can take the model they have built-in R, productionise it with the use of Docker and AWS SageMaker at ease. This will cover the training, deployment, A/B testing of the model you have built using R and some aspects of AWS and Docker.

As a Consultant at Servian, Jeno has been helping various businesses build scalable data and cloud solutions in the areas of AI/ML, Data Warehousing, Data Migration, Serverless, and Containers. He holds a Master of Data Science degree from Monash University and is a lover for R. When he is not busy roaming around Medium on the latest tech and analysing and modeling in R, he competes in Hackathons and Datathons around Melbourne.

title: Melbourne Users of R Network (MelbURN): Writing better code and getting your colleagues started with R
description:
For this meetup we have two separate presentations, the first on writing better R code, and the second on getting your colleagues started with R.

We have a new host for this one - Betfair, who will also provide catering, many thanks!

Rough agenda:
5:45: Networking, food & drinks
6:15 First presentation
7:00 Second presentation
7:45 More networking
8:30 Close

First presentation: betteR - Learnings from an everyday pursuit of wanting to write better R code

At any point in time, when I look back at my code from 6 months ago, I generally hate it and am able to say to myself that I'm glad I do this in a better manner. This is roughly my motto of continuous improvement and I'd like to share with the MelbURN community, a collection of learnings that I have acquired over the past few years. Whether it is following the DRY principle, or vowing to never write a for loop again, or learning to prepare recipes and bake them in R, a lot of things I have learnt have made me feel a lot better about how problems are tackled. Unlike other talks where you might learn about a particular package or technique, this talk will introduce you to some of the ways in which you can think about and be better at writing R code.

Kaushik Lakshman is a data scientist and a massive fan of R. He works at Betfair where he uses R to analyse the incredibly rich and extensive betting exchange data, to create data products and create business value using data science. Outside of work he loves to have a go at building sports prediction models with the hope that one day it will help him retire at the beach (but has so far been very unsuccessful)!

Second presentation: Getting your colleagues started with R

R is fantastic piece of software which is widely used in academia and commercial sector – if you are coming to this talk then you are likely already a fan. In this presentation Lyndon will draw on his experience of teaching R to hundreds of academics and business professionals (and thousands of students) to discuss tips, tricks, and things to consider when introducing and teaching your colleagues how to use R. This will include different approaches to teaching and supporting colleagues, some useful tools and resources, and the different needs and support that your colleagues may require.

Dr Lyndon Walker is a former statistics lecturer who is now a part-time statistician for SACS Consulting - a psychometrics and organisational psychology company, founder of Veritate Data Science - an education and statistics training consultancy, and investor/advisor to Preventure - a workplace safety wearable tech startup. He has used R for 22 years.

title: ODSC Birmingham Data Science: ODSC EUROPE 2019
description:
Buy your ticket at:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/odsc-europe-2019-open-data-science-conference-tickets-54242269087?discount=Meetup19

About the Conference
The annual ODSC Europe in London brings together the most influential data scientists, practitioners, innovators, and thought leaders in Data Science, Artificial Intelligence and Big Data. ODSC Europe showcases the best and the brightest when it comes to Data Science, including many open-source data science pioneers.

Learn from leading 120+ experts in hands-on trainings, workshops and talks on everything you need in applied data science and artificial intelligence.

Day One - Accelerate AI and Training Sessions
The Accelerate AI Business Summit holds talks and panels about the Business of AI and data science plus network with industry leaders.

Day Two - Training Sessions
Enhance your data science skills through training sessions taught by world-class data science instructors, in small class sizes. Here you'll strengthen your technical skills and boost your professional profile through hands-on trainings led by core contributors.

Day's Three and Four - Workshop and Talk Sessions
Further your data science knowledge and connect with like-minded individuals at the many conference talks and workshops.
Tools, Topics, and Languages
Impress your boss and colleagues with the skills you gain at ODSC Europe. Here’s just a sample of the tools, topics, and languages we'll be covering in 4 days:

Topics:

Recommendation Systems, Transfer Learning, Machine Vision, Autonomous Machines, Conversational AI, Data Science Research, Artificial Intelligence, Speech Recognition, Unsupervised Learning, Image Classification, Self-driving Vehicles, and Machine Translation

Languages:

Python, R Julia, Scala, Pig/Hive/NoSQL

Tools:

Python, Jupyter Notebooks, R programming, Julia, Scala, Stan, Apache Spark, MLlib, Streaming, Tensorflow, MXNet, Caffe, CNTK, Scikit-learn, Theano, Shogun, Pylearn2, Azure ML, Amazon ML,H20.ai, Cloud ML, Neo4J, D3.js, R-Shiny, Hadoop, Apache Storm, Apache Flink, Kafka, Druid

Networking Opportunities
Connect with 1,800 of your data science peers from around the world at these networking opportunities provided throughout the conference:

Daily Coffee Breaks / Review the talks over coffee
Career Expo / Cross paths with startups and Fortune 500 companies looking to hire talented data scientists
Office Hours Session / Drop in and bring your questions, big and small
Share a meal and ideas with like-minded individuals at Dinner with Data Scientists. (This a self-organized event. ODSC suggests the venue and provides a signup sheet. Each individual is responsible for their own dinner cost.)

title: ODSC Delhi Data Science: Developing AI Solution Mindset & Intro to Meta Heuristics and it’s Applications
description:
This meetup is supported by 91springboard.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Arbnqj6P9P4

Full agenda:
[masked] Registration, ODSC intro.
[masked]springboard space overview
[masked] Developing Artificial Intelligence Solution Mindset by Vikas Jain
[masked] Break
[masked] Implement Meta Heuristics Technique and learn its importance in ML Optimization by Chirag Sharma
[masked] Lunch Break, Group Photo, Networking

Speaker #1: Vikas Jain, Keynote Speaker on Artificial Intelligence, Business Motivation & Leadership Development | Author | Founder & CEO
https://www.linkedin.com/in/vikasjainlive/

Topic #1: Developing Artificial Intelligence Solution Mindset

Abstract:
Develop functional knowledge of Artificial Intelligence (AI) so that business leaders & professionals from IT/non-IT Industry can use it to solve complex problems and grow their business.

Speaker's Bio:
Vikas Jain is a leading Keynote and Motivational Speaker. He is a catalyst of change for Businesses and Individuals. He has delivered 170+ talks for Fortune 500 companies and other top organizations across industries including Yamaha, Oracle, Intel, Uber, PayTM – BFI, Microsoft Sales Meet, Nasscom, TIE and many more. He is an author, facilitator, and coach. He offers customized talks/programs on topics including Artificial Intelligence, Leadership, Change, Business Motivation, Life Transformation and more.

He is the founder of "Adhyan Group" and "The Real Education". Prior to starting his entrepreneurial venture, he has worked for 8+ years as a software professional with IBM and McAfee.

Duration: 45 minutes

Speaker #2 Chirag Sharma, Machine Learning Engineer at Growth Vision Consulting
https://www.linkedin.com/in/iamchiragsharma/

Topic #2:
Introduction to Meta Heuristics and Applications of Evolutionary Strategies

Abstract:
While doing the noble cause of AI we generally don’t pay attention to the details that our AI uses are derived from the various disciplines, Evolutionary Strategies are of that kind. They are derived from the biological aspects.

We are going to explore deeper into their implementation and how they provide better results when the problems are not confined by fixed logics and problems having computationally higher demands.

Speaker's Bio:
Chirag, Btech CSE student from New Delhi. He along with his Co Founder Akshey provide analytical solutions and insights via AI/ML on traditional and alternate data points.As a hobby he creates algorithms for financial purpose.

Prerequisite:
Basic understanding of python and just theoretical knowledge of metaheuristics which take less than 30 minutes to get familiar with.

Duration: 90 minutes

title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: Future of AI
description:
We have another exciting AI meetup.

Our speaker Aaron Edell says that: After selling my machine learning startup Machine Box to Veritone, Inc. in 2018, I've had a chance to reflect, research, and experience where and how businesses are spending their money on ML.

This talk is to share my experience navigating the business of applied machine learning, where we saw the most adoption and financial success, and where I would turn my attention to next.

Agenda:

5:50 pm - 6:00 pm Arrival and socializing
6:00 pm - 6:10 pm Opening words
6:10 pm - 7:10 pm Aaron Edell, "Future of AI"
7:10 pm - 7:30 pm Q&A

About Aaron Edell:

Aaron Edell is a veteran speaker and writer on the topics of machine learning, metadata, and content management. He was the co-founder and CEO of Machine Box, Inc., an award-winning startup that builds production-ready machine learning models that anyone can integrate, deploy and scale which was acquired by Veritone in September of 2018. Previously, he helped found and grow Graymeta, Inc., a machine learning and metadata company. Prior to that Edell was at Oracle, Front Porch Digital, Neulion, and SAMMA Systems in various roles from senior solutions architect to product manager. Aaron has published papers on metadata and machine learning and consulted major media and entertainment companies on content management since 2005.

title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: (Robot) Data Scientists as a Service
description:
We have another exciting Data Science meetup.

As companies collect more and more data, there is a growing need for trained professionals to build models out of those data: humans, however, are costly and do not scale too well. On the opposite side of the spectrum, tools for automated data analysis promise to do everything with one click; in reality, they are often just a list of pre-compiled models, with huge variance in accuracy and interpretability.

In this talk, we will try to find some middle ground by taking a fresh look at "symbolic regression", i.e. the idea that you can fit arbitrary datasets by evolving a population of mathematical expressions until you find something that fits data well enough. Instead of taking the standard optimization route provided by genetic algorithms, we will borrow ideas from probabilistic programming to build a small "robot scientist" with webPPL: if mathematics is a language, why can't we use ideas from natural language processing to explore the space of expressions?

Agenda:

5:50 pm - 6:00 pm Arrival and socializing
6:00 pm - 6:10 pm Opening
6:10 pm - 7:10 pm Jacopo Tagliabue, "(Robot) Data Scientists as a Service"
7:10 pm - 7:30 pm Q&A

About Jacopo Tagliabue:

Jacopo Tagliabue was co-founder and nerd in chief at Tooso - a Gartner “Cool Vendor” company that was acquired in 2019 by world search leader Coveo. Before Tooso, he has been a Best & Brightest fellow at the Santa Fe Institute and led the Data Science team of AxonVibe in New York.

In previous lives, he managed to get a Ph.D. in Cognitive Science (UNISR/MIT), do sciency things for a professional basketball team, simulate a pre-Columbian civilization and give an academic talk on video games (among others improbable "achievements"). His research and industry work has been featured several times in international conferences and the general press.

Are you interested in finding jobs in Machine Learning or would you like to gain a new set of technical skills? This Bootcamp is for you!

Professor Yasin Ceran with his valuable years of experience in understanding and modeling data has meticulously designed this Bootcamp. Our goal is to get you started in your career path and then prepare you for interviews.

We will walk you step-by-step into the Machine Learning – ML – realm and provide you with all the fundamentals of ML including linear regression, logistic regression, supervised and unsupervised learnings, decision trees and so on. With every session, you will develop new skills and improve your understanding of ML while you practice with small projects and homework. title: Bay Area Data Science Enthusiasts: Data Science Talk #1
description:
In the real world, training datasets are not as readily available as Kaggle would have you believe. In certain situations, they are extremely costly to obtain, while in others they are impossible. In this talk, I will describe two cases where we had to get creative to obtain training datasets. I want an argumentative environment where we can discuss our ideas.

Record linkage is a classic problem in statistics and machine learning. There are two datasets, with several fields in common, but no unique identifiers as match keys. Due to a lack of ground truth training dataset, unsupervised learning techniques are usually employed. However, we embarked on an ambitious project to create a training dataset using unsupervised learning, and feed that to a machine learning model which then learned to make predictions of match or no match.

In the second project, we had to extract handwritten information from checks. The hard part of the problem is recognizing fields like dates, signatures etc on a check. The costly way would be to have human raters mark each field with coordinates. However, we decided to create a fake training dataset where we automatically generated date fields (populated with handwritten dates) and used that to train a classifier that recognized real date fields on checks.

Agenda:

6:20 pm - 6:30 pm Arrival and socializing
6:30 pm - 6:40 pm Opening words
6:40 pm - 7:50 pm Ahmad Emad, "Data Science Talk #1"
7:50 pm - 8:00 pm Q&A

About Ahmad Emad:

Ahmad Emad is currently a Data Scientist at Google, where he applies experiment design and machine learning techniques to make Google Assistant more useful and user-friendly. Prior to Google, Ahmad was a Data Scientist at Capital One building fraud detection models. Ahmad has a Masters in Statistics from The George Washington University and a Bachelors in Computer Science and Economics from Colgate University. In his free time, Ahmad enjoys reading, hiking and trying out new food places.

title: ODSC Milano Data Science: Combining Voice, Personalization&Search to discover your next favorite artist
description:
This meetup is supported by Microsoft.

Agenda:
7:00pm - 7:30pm - ODSC Intro, Networking
7:30pm - 8:20pm - Talk
8:20pm - 8:30pm - Q&A
8:30pm - 9:00pm - Networking, Pizza & Refreshments

Speaker:
Massimo Quadrana, Scientist at Pandora
https://www.linkedin.com/in/massimoquadrana/

Bio:
Massimo is a Scientist at Pandora, the largest audio entertainment company in the US. He holds an M.Sc. in Computer Engineering and Ph.D. from Politecnico di Milano on “Sequence-Aware Recommender Systems”.
He is passionate about Machine Learning, especially of Recommender Systems and their application to music. In the past years, he has presented several scientific papers and given tutorials on these topics at top-tier conferences like ACM RecSys and TheWebConf. In his spare time, he enjoys playing the vinyl records he collects from stores all over the world.

Topic:
Combining Voice, Personalization and Search to discover your next favorite artist

Abstract:
The wide adoption of voice-enabled devices has opened the doors to a new, seemingly unconstrained interaction with the music we love.
The new ways in which listeners can interact with music and podcasts has originated a variety of new challenges and exciting opportunities for music service providers.

In this talk, we will showcase some of the most interesting challenges that we have faced in designing the new Voice Mode at Pandora. Specifically, we will describe how personalization and recommendation techniques can be leveraged to handle voice queries of different types (known-item, thematic and open-ended queries) to empower tens of millions of listeners to discover their next favorite artist as naturally as they were talking directly to a friend.

title: Data Science Study Group: South Florida: Study Group Session + Lightning Talks
group: Data Science Study Group: South Florida
description:
We'll dedicate time during Study Group Sessions for short talks as well as Q&A.

If you would like to present a 10 to 20 minute talk on a data-related topic (e.g. language, tool, concept, or statistical technique) at this Wednesday's Meetup, message us.

This is a friendly environment where all questions are appreciated and where members learn from each other.

Bring your questions and your know-how. Stuck on a problem or you're not clear on something? Ask away. Did you figure out something awesome and would like to share it? Plug in to the monitor and take the floor.

R, Python, Julia, SQL, BI tool? Great!

All experience levels and career backgrounds are welcomed. Join us!

Bring a laptop to maximize participation.

Parking Instructions: Please note that the RSVP list will be shared with MDC for access to the parking garage. Enter the garage, Building 7, from the 5th Street entrance.

title: ODSC Amsterdam Data Science: Self supervised representation learning
description:
Speaker: Pratyush Kumar Sinha, Senior digital strategist - machine learning
https://www.linkedin.com/in/pratyushsinhahec/

Speaker's Bio:
With 13 years of experience in building high impact data science products such as customer segmentation, chatbots, recommendation system, time series modeling, anomaly detection and leading technical sales for machine learning in Europe for a large consulting organization, he evolved into the role of a senior digital strategist. Now, he assists businesses in improving their advanced analytics practice to get actionable insights from data and discover monetization opportunities.

Topic: Self-supervised representation learning

Abstract:
We need to learn the representation of statistical objects hidden in data so that we could do classification and aggregation tasks on them. Mostly these representations are learnt by providing constraints in forms of labels. How could we learn these representations without labels? What should be the property of these representations? Existing methods are Autoencoders which are non-linear PCA, clustering, Autoregressive models
But can we be creative?

Agenda:
6:00pm - 6:30pm - ODSC Intro, Pizza & Refreshments
6:30pm - 7:10pm - Talk
7:10pm - 7:20pm - Q&A
7:20pm - 7:50pm - Networking

title: ODSC Austin Data Science: Designing & Building Enterprise Knowledge Graphs from Relational Databases
description:
This meetup supported by data.world

Speaker: Juan Sequeda, Principal Scientist at data.world
https://www.linkedin.com/in/juansequeda/

Bio:
Juan F. Sequeda is the Principal Scientist at data.world. He joined through the acquisition of Capsenta, a company he founded as a spin-off from his research. He holds a Ph.D. in Computer Science from The University of Texas at Austin.

Schedule:
6:00pm - 6:30pm - ODSC Intro, Pizza & Refreshments
6:30pm - 7:20pm - Talk
7:20pm - 7:30pm - Q&A
7:30pm - 8:00pm - Networking

Topic:
Designing & Building Enterprise Knowledge Graphs from Relational Databases in the Real World

Abstract:
Knowledge Graphs are fulfilling the vision of creating intelligent systems that integrate knowledge and large scale data. We observe the adoption of Knowledge Graphs by the Googles of the world. However, not everybody is Google. Enterprises still struggle to understand their relational databases consisting of thousands of tables, tens of thousands of attributes and how the data all work together. How can enterprise adopt Knowledge Graphs successfully to address Data Integration and Business Intelligence needs, without boiling the ocean?

title: Fresno Data Science Meetup: Understanding Neural Networks
description:
Join us as we demystify neural networks by exploring what a neural network is, how it learns so effectively and the differences between shallow and deep neural networks. The goal is to provide attendees with a fundamental understanding.

Neural networks are an imperative part of machine learning and are the foundation of much of artificial intelligence. If you're interested in Deep Learning, Artificial Intelligence or working with unstructured data (audio, video, images, text), then understanding neural networks is a must.

(We have not scheduled a room yet so check back as the event approaches to find out in what room this Meetup will be held.)

Food and drinks will be provided.

AGENDA

6:00 p.m. - Food and mingle

6:30 p.m. - Welcome

6:45 p.m. - Main talk

8:00 p.m. - More mingling

8:15 p.m. - End

title: ODSC Zurich Data Science: Time Series Prediction - A short comparison of best practices
description:
Speaker: Thomas Ebermann, Data Scientist at Liip
https://www.linkedin.com/in/dr-thomas-ebermann-a5ba0614/

Topic:
Time Series Prediction - A short comparison of best practices

Schedule:
6:30pm - 7:00pm - ODSC Intro
7:00pm - 7:50pm - Talk
7:50pm - 8:00pm - Q&A
8:00pm - 8:30pm - Networking and Apero

Bio:
Thomas Ebermann is the lead of the Liip data services group. He background is both in computer science and communications science, where he studied the research of information flow in social networks online. These days he and his team develop data-centric products with the user at heart. He has more than 8 years of experience crunching data for big Swiss media- and advertising companies. In his free time, he teaches data skills to data journalists and students at the HTW Chur and the University of Zürich.

Abstract:
Are you trying to predict time series but don't know where to start? This talk will provide a comparison of the most prominent techniques and show you how to implement them.
